intro: Plagiobothrys hispidus var. foliaceus, commonly known as the woolly bladderpod, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes mustard and cabbage plants. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and small, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. Its leaves are typically oval and covered in fine, white hairs, giving it a woolly appearance. This variety is often found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils.
